page.title: 02LAND USE IN BERKELEY VALE
page.content: This area is in the middle of the Severn's flood plain, which stretches from the Forest of Dean to the Cotswolds. The land is clay because of flooding in the past and is chiefly used for{grazing;}mainly{dairy cattle and a few{horses.}In the fields to the south and west of Ham permanent jumps have been set up for horse trials. Other fields are uesd to make{silage and{hay}for winter fodder for animals. {Fruit trees}which once were sheltered in the orchards by elms are now exposed due to{dutch elm disease having killed many of the elms. The exposed fruit trees are now also dying off leaving fields uneven and only fit for livestock. Unfortunately due to lack of possible returns new fruit trees are not being planted, so it would seem that this area of land will eventaully become even more exposed.
